Assembly of polyoxometalate with graphene foam as a compressible monolithic catalyst for biodiesel production Xiaoting Jing Investigation Data curation Formal analysis Writing - original draft Zhen Li Software Formal analysis Bing Lu Software Yuyang Han Software Yingnan Chi Conceptualization Methodology Validation Writing - review & editing Supervision * Changwen Hu Validation Supervision Key Laboratory of Cluster Science Ministry of Education, Beijing Key Laboratory of Photoelectronic/Electrophotonic Conversion Materials, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, 100081, People’s Republic of China Key Laboratory of Cluster Science Ministry of Education Beijing Key Laboratory of Photoelectronic/Electrophotonic Conversion Materials School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 People’s Republic of China Key Laboratory of Cluster Science Ministry of Education, Beijing Key Laboratory of Photoelectronic/Electrophotonic Conversion Materials, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, 100081, People’s Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Compressible monolithic catalysts exhibit remarkable advantages over traditional powder ones, but the fabrication of polyoxometalate (POM)-containing compressible catalyst is rarely explored. Herein, a compressible monolith, PW12@GF, has been fabricated by immobilizing H3PW12O40 (PW12) catalyst on elastic graphene foam (GF). Moreover, FT-IR and XPS spectra analysis and leaching test reveal that the delocalization of protons on POM occurs during the assembly of PW12@GF, and the delocalized protons connect POM and GF into a stable composite. Importantly, biodiesel production is effectively promoted by PW12@GF under mild conditions (60 °C) without stirring, and the product can be easily separated from the catalyst by compression. Moreover, its catalytic activity is basically maintained after five cycles. Notably, the catalytic activity of PW12@GF (conversion: 97 %) in the heterogeneous system is even comparable to that of homogeneous PW12 and strong Brønsted acidity and the lipophilic surface of the catalyst account for the excellent performance. Keywords Polyoxometalate Biodiesel production Compressible monolithic catalyst Graphene foam Heterogeneous catalysis 1 Introduction The development of biodiesel is one of the effective solutions to meet the growing energy demand. Compared with petroleum diesel, biodiesel is a renewable, biodegradable, and environmental-friendly energy source, which is generally synthesized by esterification or transesterification reaction using vegetable oils, animal fats, or free fatty acids as raw materials [1–5]. To achieve high conversion under mild conditions, the design of catalysts is the key. Up to now, several kinds of catalysts have been developed, including acids [6], bases [7–9], and biological enzymes [10,11]. Among them, the acid-catalyzed esterification reaction has attracted considerable attention due to the reduced cost and no saponification problem. Strong Brønsted acids, such as sulfuric acid, hydrochloric acid, phosphoric acid, and organic sulfonic acids, were commonly used [12,13]. However, these liquid acid-based catalysts usually have the disadvantages of causticity and difficulty in recycling. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are a well-known class of anionic metal-oxo clusters with diverse structures and excellent properties [14,15]. Given their tunable Brønsted acidity and good thermal stability, POMs were widely used as a kind of green solid acid catalysts [16–18]. Comparing to traditional inorganic acids (e.g., H2SO4 and HNO3), POMs are less corrosive and do not lead to sulfonation or nitration side reaction. Nevertheless, POMs have high solubility in polar solvents and very low surface areas, which make their applications as heterogeneous catalysts limited. To improve recyclability, POMs are generally immobilized on functional supports with high surface area and pH stability. In the synthesis of biodiesel, different supports have been used including metal oxides (tantalum oxide [19], zirconia [20], alumina [21], etc.), clays [22,23], silica [24,25], zeolites [26], carbons [27–29], and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [30]. For example, POMs and sulfonated ionic liquids were immobilized on MOFs in Xie’s group, and the synthesized materials can effectively catalyze the transesterification and esterification of acidic vegetable oils [30]. To achieve the rapid separation of catalyst from reaction mixture, a series of magnetic hybrid nanocomposites with core–shell structure were synthesized and used as catalytic materials for the biodiesel production [31–33]. However, since most of the supported-POMs are powder catalysts, they require mechanical stirring during catalysis followed by time-consuming catalyst separation process (such as centrifugation, filtration, and washing, etc.) after catalysis. For industrial mass production, a compressible monolithic catalyst is more desirable. The compressible catalyst can effectively adsorb reactants, which are converted into target products by the immobilized active sites without stirring. Importantly, after the reaction, products are readily separated from catalysts by compression. However, the reported examples of compressible catalysts are very limited. For example, a compressible monolith was synthesized in Chang’s group by immobilizing Ag on a microporous organic polymer sponge, that showed good catalytic activity and recyclability in the reduction reaction of 4-nitrophenol [34]. Recently, in the same group, cobalt nanoparticles supported on a compressible microporous polymer was used to catalyze the tandem reaction giving amine products [35]. To our knowledge, POMs-containing compressible catalyst is rarely explored. Graphene is an interesting 2D material and has wide applications in the fields of catalysis, adsorption, and energy conversion. Because of large surface area, intriguing electronic structure, and excellent thermal and chemical stability, graphene is also an ideal support to disperse different types of catalysts [36–38]. As a result, a number of POMs-graphene composites have been fabricated, mainly used in supercapacitor [39–41], electrocatalysis [42–44], and proton conduction [45]. The special surface environment of graphene is not only suitable to immobilize POMs but also can improve the compatibility of hydrophilic POMs with hydrophobic organic substrate. Recently, a robust 3D graphene foam (GF) with a multioriented microladder structure has been prepared in Qu’s group by the Tween-80-assisted freeze-casting process [46]. The outstanding elasticity of this material combined with the intrinsic properties of graphene makes it a suitable support to fabricate POMs-containing compressible catalyst. In this work, a compressible monolithic catalyst containing heterogenized and evenly dispersed POM has been successfully fabricated by immobilizing H3PW12O40 (PW12) on elastic graphene foam (GF). The synthesized PW12@GF composite has been characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), Raman spectra, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Interestingly, the PW12@GF as a compressible monolith can efficiently catalyze the esterification reaction to produce biodiesel. Under mild conditions, 97 % of lauric acid is converted in 6 h without stirring, and its catalytic activity is even comparable to that of homogeneous PW12. Moreover, the produced biodiesel can be easily separated from the catalyst by compression, and the catalyst can be reused for five cycles with no significant loss of its catalytic activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods The chemicals including pristine graphite powders (325 mesh), sulfuric acid (95 %–98 %), hydrochloric acid (75 %), sodium nitrate (99 %), potassium permanganate (99.5 %), hydrogen peroxide (aqueous solution, 30 wt%), methanol (>99.9 %), biphenyl (≥99 %), phosphotungstic acid (99 %), lauric acid (>98 %), myristic acid (≥99.5 %), palmitic acid (≥99 %), methyl dodecanoate (99 %), methyl myristate (≥98 %), methyl hexadecanoate (≥98 %) and Tween-80 (AR) were all purchased from Aladdin and used without further purification. All the used reagents were analytically pure. The morphology and microstructure of the samples were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JOEL JSE-7500F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JOEL JEM-2010). Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were conducted on a Bruker instrument (D8 Venture) equipped with graphite-monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.154 nm) in the range of 5° to 55°. The Fourier transform infrared spectrometry (FT-IR) analyses were measured on a Nicolet 170SXFT-IR spectrophotometer in the range 400–4000 cm−1. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) C 1s and W 4f spectra of the samples were performed on Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi. The UV–vis spectroscopy was measured on UV-2600. The isoelectric point (IEP) was conducted on Nicomp Z3000. The Raman spectra were obtained on SNFT-SRLab1000. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was performed on Thermo Scientific iCAPQ. The esterification reaction for biodiesel production was monitored by gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014C) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a HP-5 ms capillary column. The acid strength and acidity of PW12@GF were characterized by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (PCA-1200). 2.2 Synthesis of graphene oxide Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared by a modified Hummers’ method. Graphite (9.0 g, 325 mesh) and sodium nitrate (4.5 g) were added to concentrated sulfuric acid (210 mL) and stirred in an ice-water bath for 2 h. Then, potassium permanganate (27.0 g) was slowly added, and the temperature of the suspension was kept below 20 °C. Subsequently, the reaction system was stirred in a water bath of 35–40 °C for about 0.5 h to form a thick paste. Then, 420 mL of water was added, and the solution was stirred at 80 °C for 20 min, an additional 1000 mL of water was added. After cooling to room temperature, 60 mL of H2O2 (30 %) was slowly added, and the color of the solution changed from brown to yellow. After filtering, the obtained yellow precipitate was washed with 1:1 and 1:9 HCl aqueous solution (250 mL) to remove the residual metal ions, respectively. The resulting solid was dispersed in water by sonication for 1 h to prepare a GO aqueous dispersion. The resulting brown dispersion was then centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 1 h and centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 1 h to remove any aggregates. Finally, GO was further purified by dialysis for one week. 2.3 Synthesis of PW12@GF 4.5 mL GO (5.7 mg / mL), phosphotungstic acid (25.6 mg), and 0.4 mL Tween-80 (sparkling agent, 100 mg / mL, ethanol solution) were mixed in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred vigorously with a magnetic stirrer (1500 rpm) for 10 min. During the reaction, obvious color change from brown to yellow was observed. The foamed solution was poured into a vessel and placed in liquid nitrogen. When the solution is completely frozen, the vessel was placed in a freeze dryer for three days. The obtained PW12@GOS was annealed at 200 °C for 2 h, 4 h, or 6 h under Ar / H2 atmosphere. During the annealing treatment, PW12@GOS was reduced to PW12@GF. After annealing, PW12@GF was immersed in a methanol solution to remove unloaded PW12. Finally, the catalyst was dried overnight at 100 °C. The pressure on the foam withstanding a 200 g mass in Fig. 1 can be calculated according to the Eq. (1): (1) P = F / S = G / S = mg / [π(d/2)2] 2.4 Procedure for NH3-TPD The acid strength and acidity of PW12@GF were characterized by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD). First, 19 mg of sample was loaded and treated at 200 °C for 120 min under Ar blow at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. Then, it was flushed with NH3 at 80 °C for 30 min and cooled to room temperature. The samples were heated under Ar atmosphere from 30 °C to 350 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C / min and kept at 350 °C for 200 min. The NH3 gas was continuously detected by a thermal conductivity detector. 2.5 Catalytic esterification for biodiesel production A fabricated PW12@GF (diameter: 15 mm, height: 10 mm, mass: 0.03 g) was put into a vessel, and a reaction solution containing lauric acid (2 mmol), biphenyl (1 mmol, internal standard), and methanol (100 mmol) was added dropwise. After compressing the catalyst several times, the reaction solution was completely absorbed by the catalyst. Then the sealed vessel was heated to 60 °C, and the esterification reaction was conducted for 6 h without any other treatment. At various time intervals, after compressing catalyst several times, aliquots were removed and then analyzed by GC. To investigate the influence of methanol amount on biodiesel production, 60 mmol, 80 mmol, or 100 mmol of methanol was used and other reactants were constant: lauric acid (2 mmol), biphenyl (1 mmol, internal standard), and a block of PW12@GF (17 wt%). To investigate the influence of lauric acid amount on biodiesel production, 0.5 mmol, 1 mmol, or 2 mmol of lauric acid was used and other reactants were constant: methanol (100 mmol), biphenyl (1 mmol, internal standard), and a block of PW12@GF (17 wt%). For the recycle test, the reaction solution is separated from the catalyst by compression after six hours, and the obtained PW12@GF was washed with methanol three times and then dried at 100 °C in an oven and used for the next cycle. The apparent transformation frequency (TOF h−1) was calculated by Eq. (2), where nconv is the amount of converted acid, t is the reaction time (h), and nHPW is the amount of immobilized PW12 in PW12@GF. (2) TOF = nconv / (nPW12 × t) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of PW12@GF compressible monolith 3.1.1 Synthesis of PW12@GF compressible monolith The Keggin-type PW12 with strong Brønsted acidity was used to combine with elastic GF, and PW12@GF was fabricated by freezing-dry and subsequent low-temperature annealing. As shown in Scheme 1 , graphene oxide (GO), TWEEN-80, and PW12 with an optimized ratio were mixed and vigorously stirred. Due to the addition of sparkling agent TWEEN-80, a large number of bubbles were generated under vigorous stirring, and GO sheets were aggregated around the formed micron-sized bubbles. Then the obtained mixture was freeze-dried for three days to form a 3D PW12@GOS (graphene oxide sheets), the shape of the monolithic catalyst can be regulated by choosing different molds. Finally, PW12@GF was obtained after annealing at low temperature (200 °C) under Ar / H2 atmosphere. The synthesized PW12@GF monolith shows satisfactory elasticity and can withstand the pressure of 11097 Pa without shape change (Figs. 1 and S1). 3.1.2 Characterization of PW12@GF compressible monolith The SEM image of PW12@GF in Fig. 2 a shows a typical 3D skeleton of GF, where graphene sheets interconnect with each other forming micron-sized cavities. This unique microstructure results in its excellent elasticity. Moreover, compared with the image of 3D GF synthesized by using a similar method without adding POMs, no obvious structural change is observed (Fig. S2). The TEM image (Fig. 2b) indicates that wrinkled graphene sheets are maintained in the composite and PW12 clusters (the black dots) with the average diameter of about 10 nm are evenly deposited on the sheets. The homogeneous dispersion of PW12 on the GF is further confirmed by elemental mapping measurements (Figs. 2c–d and S3). According to the SEM image (Fig. 2a), the pore size of PW12@GF is on the scale of micrometer, and the formed macroporous structure facilitates mass transfer in the catalytic process. The PXRD patterns of PW12, GF, and PW12@GF are shown in Fig. 3 a. The facts, there is a broad diffraction peak of GF at about 25° in the XRD pattern of PW12@GF but no characteristic peak of GO at around 11°, indicate that GO is reduced during the annealing process. No diffraction peaks of Keggin-type PW12 crystals is observed in the XRD pattern of PW12@GF, displaying that PW12 clusters are uniformly dispersed on GF and that is consistent with the result of TEM. The loading amount of PW12 is calculated to be 17 wt%, according to ICP analyses. The Raman spectra of GF and PW12@GF (Fig. 3b) display two evident vibrations: a D band at 1352 cm−1 attributed to the defects on graphene sheets and a G band at 1591 cm−1 corresponding to the sp2-hybridized carbon [47]. The similar D and G band positions of GF and PW12@GF reveal that the introduction of POMs does not affect the structure of GF support. However, after immobilizing PW12, the characteristic absorption peaks of PW12 basically disappear possibly due to the high dispersion of POM on the support [48]. The intensity ratio of D and G bands (ID / IG) decreases from 1 to 0.83 reflects that defects and disorders decrease in PW12@GF. 3.2 Interactions between PW12 catalyst and elastic GF support 3.2.1 FT-IR spectrum The FT-IR spectra of PW12, GF, and PW12@GF are shown in Fig. 4 . There are four types of oxygen atoms: Oa (central PO4 tetrahedron oxygen atoms), Od (terminal oxygen atoms), Ob (corner-shared oxygen atoms), and Oc (edge-shared oxygen atoms) (Fig. 4a). In the FT-IR spectrum of PW12, four characteristic absorption peaks at 1077, 977, 903, and 789 cm−1 are attributed to the vibrations of the P–Oa, W = Od, W-Ob-W, and W-Oc-W, respectively [49,50]. For GF, CO symmetry vibration peak appears at 1731 cm−1, CC characteristic peak at 1587 cm−1, and the COC at 1246 cm−1. The PW12@GF composite has all the characteristic absorption peaks of POM cluster, indicating that the PW12 is successfully immobilized on GF without structural damage. Compared with starting material PW12, the absorption peaks of P-Oa, W = Od, and W-Ob-W in PW12@GF are basically unchanged (±5 cm−1), while the W-Oc-W vibration undergoes a blue shift from 789 cm−1 to 828 cm−1 (Fig. 4b). The remarkable shift of 39 cm−1 suggests that there are strong interactions between PW12 and GF support. The strong interaction between PW12 and GF is also proven by the leaching test. When a block of PW12@GF was soaked in methanol for 24 h, no characteristic absorption peak of PW12 was detected by UV–vis spectroscopy (Fig. S4a). Although the interactions between POM and rGO or other carbon materials have been studied, it is still not well understood. As the existence of oxygen-containing functional groups, such as hydroxyls and carbonyls, some investigations speculate that rGO might be protonated under acidic conditions and accordingly POM polyanion and positively charged rGO could be combined by electrostatic interactions. However, isoelectric point measurement displays that the surface of 3D GF we prepared is always negatively charged in the pH range of 1.5 to 4.5 (Fig. S5). The pH of our reaction solution is about 2.2, under which the protonation of GF is hardly performed. Barteau et al. reported that the charge delocalization of POM has a great influence on its IR spectrum [51]. Therefore, we speculate that the blue shift of W-Oc-W vibration in PW12@GF is possibly caused by the delocalization of proton located on Oc atoms. The delocalization of H+ could lead to the increase of electron density around Oc atoms, and as a result, W-Oc bond length is shortened, and the frequency of W-Oc-W shifts towards higher energy. This speculation is further supported by XPS data. The XPS spectrum of PW12@GF in the W 4f region shows two peaks at 36.1 and 38.2 eV, which are assigned to W (VI) oxidation state (Fig. S6). In contrast, the W 4f binding energy of PW12 is 36.3 and 38.4 eV, respectively. The slight decrease of W 4f binding energy (0.2 eV) indicates that the electron density around W atoms increases due to the delocalization of proton. The delocalized protons as glue connect POM cluster and GF into a robust composite. 3.2.2 Role of annealing in the fabrication of PW12@GF compressible monolith Interestingly, we find that annealing treatment plays a role in the formation of robust PW12@GF composite. In the IR spectrum of PW12@GOF (Fig. 5 ), the sample before annealing, a blue shift of 31 cm−1 for the W-Oc-W vibration is found. However, the interactions between POMs and GF support are not strong enough evidenced by the apparent leaching of POM (Fig. S7a). Notably, the interactions between POMs and support are reinforced during the annealing treatment. As shown in Fig. 5, after annealing, the vibration of W-Oc-W further removes from 820 cm−1 to 828 cm−1. Moreover, the control experiments show that with the increase of annealing time from 2 h to 4 h and 6 h, the immobilization of POMs becomes more and more stable (Fig. S7b–d). For example, after 2 h of annealing treatment, slight leaching of POM still can be detected, but after 4 h or 6 h annealing no leaching is found. Nevertheless, after 6 h annealing, the GF becomes less elastic and so 4 h was used as the optimal annealing time. The XPS spectra of GO, GF, PW12, and PW12@GF are shown in Fig. S8. Obviously, the intensity of oxygen peak (532 eV) in PW12@GF became much lower than that in starting material GO, indicating that GO is partially reduced during the annealing process. Moreover, the phosphorus (134.65 eV) and tungsten peaks (36.25 eV) are found in the XPS of PW12@GF, confirming the successful immobilization of PW12. The high-resolution C 1s XPS of GF and PW12@GF with different annealing time (2 h, 4 h, and 6 h) are shown in Fig. 6 . Four types of carbon environments are found at 284.8 eV (CC), 286.3 eV (CO), 287.3 eV (CO), and 289.1 eV (OCO), respectively. It is obvious that for the same annealing time the peak intensity of CO in PW12@GF is dramatically lower than that in GF. In other words, as the introduction of POMs more hydroxyl groups on GF are reduced. The possible reason is that POMs provide a large amount of proton, promoting the reduction of hydroxyl groups. The previous study in Qu’s group [46] indicates that after 2 h annealing treatment at 200 °C, Tween-80 still remained in GF. Nevertheless, in our experiment at the same temperature, the sparkling agent basically disappeared (Fig. 5). To explain above results, the FT-IR spectra of GF and PW12@GF with different annealing time were compared. As shown in Fig. S9a, the characteristic absorption peak of Tween-80 at 1109 cm−1 basically disappears with the increase of annealing time to 4 h. The result shows that heating is one factor leading to the decomposition of Tween-80. As shown in Fig. S9b, for PW12@GF the characteristic absorption peak of Tween-80 basically disappears after 2 h annealing. That is, the introduction of POM accelerates the decomposition of Tween-80. Based on the above results, we think that both heating and the introduction of POMs contribute to the disappearance of Tween-80. 3.3 Production of biodiesel by PW12@GF compressible monolith 3.3.1 Influence of several reaction parameters on the catalytic activity The esterification reaction of lauric acid with methanol was selected as a model reaction to evaluate the catalytic activity of POM@GF (Fig. 7 a). As shown in Fig. 7b, in homogeneous system the Keggin-type clusters, PW12, SiW12, and PMo12, can catalyze the esterification reaction, and 86 %–97 % substrate is converted in 6 h at 60 °C. The catalytic activity order: PW12 > SiW12 > PMo12 is consistent with their Brønsted acidity order. As the best performance of PW12, it was chosen to combine with 3D GF, and PW12@GF was used in the following experiments. For a typical reaction, lauric acid (2 mmol) and biphenyl (internal standard, 1 mmol) dissolved in methanol (4 mL), and then the reaction solution was absorbed by a block of PW12@GF monolith (diameter: 15 mm, height: 10 mm). Compressible catalyst PW12@GF was placed in a vessel, and the reaction was performed under heating conditions without stirring. To explore the optimal reaction conditions, the influences of reaction temperature, time, and loading amount of POM catalyst on the production of biodiesel were systematically investigated. As shown in Fig. 7c, as the reaction temperature increases from 40 °C to 60 °C, the conversion of lauric acid increases from 66 % to 97 % in 6 h. The conversion of the substrate also increases with reaction time (Fig. 7d), and the maximum conversion (97 %) is reached after 6 h at 60 °C, and the apparent turnover frequency (TOF) of 183 h−1 was calculated relative to the number of immobilized PW12. The productivity of biodiesel is also expressed as 10.8 mmolꞏg−1ꞏh−1, which refers to the moles of converted lauric acid per gram of catalyst per hour. The loading amount of PW12 on 3D GF can be adjusted by changing the amount of POM in the starting materials, and the control experiments show that 17 wt% is the maximum loading. As shown in Fig. 7e, with the increase of PW12 loading from 6.8 wt% to 17 wt% the catalytic activity is dramatically improved from 18 % to 97 % under the optimal conditions (60 °C, 6 h). As we know, the esterification reaction is thermodynamic equilibrium. To shift the equilibrium to forward direction, excess methanol was used, which acts as both solvent and reactant. As shown in Fig. 7f, when the ratio of lauric acid to methanol changes from 1:30, 1:40 to 1:50, the conversion of lauric acid is obviously improved. In addition, the rate of the esterification reaction shows significant dependence on the amounts of lauric acid. For example, decreasing the amount of lauric acid from 2 to 0.5 mmol, the conversion decreases from 97 % to 35 % (Fig. 7g). 3.3.2 Role of POM and elastic GF in the catalytic reaction To investigate the role of GF support on the catalytic reaction, the esterification of lauric acid with methanol was conducted under the otherwise identical conditions catalyzed by elastic GF. As shown in Fig. 8 a, GF gives a negligible conversion, even though the conversion of 7 % is obtained in the blank test. Compared with the conversion of 97 % by PW12@GF, the support GF has no contribution to the catalytic reaction. As a result, the immobilized PW12 clusters are the dominated catalytic active sites, and the esterification reaction is catalyzed by the Brønsted acidity of PW12@GF. Therefore, temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) measurement for PW12@GF was performed. As shown in Fig. 9 , there are two different acid sites in the PW12@GF catalyst. The desorption peak at 100 °C belongs to weak acid sites on PW12@GF, and the one at 350 °C corresponds to mediate strong ones. The ratio of two peak areas indicates that more mediate strong acid sites are exposed in the catalyst. The total acidity capacity of PW12@GF is calculated to be 15.5 mmol / g. Remarkably, PW12@GF, as a heterogeneous catalyst, exhibits a catalytic activity comparable to that of homogeneous PW12 (Fig. 8b). Generally, POM catalysts tend to partially lose their catalytic activities after immobilization [4,22]. The excellent activity of PW12@GF might be explained by the following points. First, the catalytic material is prepared by freeze-drying and low-temperature annealing. Under such conditions, PW12 loses part of lattice water molecules, and correspondingly, the Brønsted acidity of immobilized POM is improved. Second, IR and XPS results indicate that the delocalization of protons on PW12 occurs during the formation of PW12@GF composites, and the delocalized protons are more active than the localized ones. We speculate that the excellent catalytic activity of PW12@GF is mainly attributed to the delocalization of proton. Third, the lipophilic surface of GF support is beneficial to the access of fatty acid to POM active sites. Finally, PW12 is evenly dispersed on GF support, and that increases the contact area between POM catalyst and the absorbed reactants. In addition, PW12@GF can catalyze the esterification reactions of myristic acid and palmitic acid, under optimal conditions giving the conversions of 93 % (TOF: 175 h−1) and 90 % (TOF: 170 h−1), respectively. Based on the above results, a possible reaction mechanism catalyzed by PW12@GF compressible monolithic catalyst was proposed. The fatty acid and methanol were first absorbed by the catalyst and access immobilized POMs. Then, the carbonyl oxygen of fatty acid is protonated at the acidic sites, and the subsequent nucleophilic attack of methanol gives biodiesel product. 3.3.3 Evaluation of the heterogeneity and recyclability of PW12@GF To verify the heterogeneity of PW12@GF, a leaching test was performed. As shown in Fig. 10 a, when the reaction proceeded for 1 h with the conversion of about 40 %, the reaction solution was squeezed out from the monolithic catalyst, and a negligible conversion was found under the same reaction conditions. The result shows that the PW12@GF catalyst is stable to leaching, and the 3D elastic GF is good support to immobilize POMs. To quantify the amount of leached PW12 from the GF support during five consecutive recycles, a block of the catalyst was immersed in 4 mL of methanol and heated to 60 °C for 6 h as the conditions used in a typical catalytic reaction. After 6 h heating, the solution was collected and analyzed by UV–vis spectroscopy, and the monolithic catalyst was dried and used for the next cycle. As shown in Fig. S10, no characteristic absorption peak of PW12 was observed in the UV–vis spectra after each cycle. The above results prove that there are no observable leached POMs in the recycle process. We also evaluate the recyclability of PW12@GF. After the first cycle, the reaction solution was separated from the catalyst by compression, and then the PW12@GF was washed with methanol several times. After drying, it was used for the next cycle. As shown in Fig. 10b, there is no substantial loss of the catalytic activity for PW12@GF even after five cycles. As GF support is lipophilic, the product, methyl laurate, could be absorbed by the catalyst. For the first cycle, no adsorbed methyl laurate was detected by FT-IR spectra in the catalyst after washing with methanol (Fig. S11), but after five cycles, it is found that the adsorbed product cannot be completely removed by washing (Fig. S12). We speculate that the residual product on the surface of PW12@GF accounts for the slight decrease of catalytic activity during the recycle test. In addition, the activity and recyclability of our PW12@GF composite outperform most of the POM-based heterogeneous catalysts in biodiesel production. The conversion, methanol/substrate molar ratio, reaction temperature, and reaction time from recent investigations were summarized in Table 1 . For example, PW12-SBA-15 can convert 96 % of palmitic acid in 4 h at 60 °C [24]. But the methanol/substrate molar ratio (98) is almost twice ours, and the amount of catalyst (0.2 g) is about 7 times higher than that we used. Furthermore, PW12-SBA-15 was only used for two cycles, and a slight decrease of catalytic activity was observed in the second run. For the zirconia-supported PW12, the ratio of methanol to substrate is also high, and the amount of catalyst used is ten times that of ours [4]. Due to the lack of strong interaction between POMs and support, its activity obviously decreases after each cycle. The H3PMo12O40/AC can convert 98 % lauric acid with methanol/substrate molar ratio of 50, but a relatively higher reaction temperature (70 °C) and a long reaction time (10 h) were needed [27]. In comparison, our compressible monolithic catalyst, PW12@GF, convert 97 % of lauric acid at 60 °C in 6 h without stirring. The reaction temperature and the molar ratio of methanol/substrate in our reaction are lower than or comparable to those in most reports. Importantly, PW12@GF exhibits good recyclability, and the rapid separation of the product from the catalyst can be realized by compression. A possible mechanism is proposed for the esterification reaction catalyzed by PW12@GF. The immobilized PW12 clusters with strong Brønsted acidity are the dominant active sites. Since the catalyst support GF is hydrophobic, long-chain carboxylic acid and methanol can smoothly access the hydrophilic POMs, where the esterification reaction is promoted. First, the delocalized protons on the POM is very active, which transfers to the carbonyl oxygen of carboxylic acid, enhancing the electrophilicity of carbonyl carbon. Then, methanol attacks carbonyl carbon of the carboxylic acid to generate oxonium ions on the hydroxyl oxygen of alcohol. After proton transfer, the hydroxyl group is protonated to produce a new onium ion. Finally, the onium species eliminates one water molecule, and after deprotonation, the product is obtained. According to the characteristics of PW12@GF, a visible needle tube for small-scale biodiesel production was designed, as shown in Fig. S13. In a typical reaction, three blocks of PW12@GF catalysts were put in the tube. When the liquid reactants were completely adsorbed by PW12@GF, the needle tube was heated by circulating water on its outer wall. The catalytic reaction takes place inside the tube without mechanical stirring. After the reaction, the reaction solution is easily collected by compression. Since the excellent elasticity of PW12@GF, the shape of PW12@GF monolithic catalyst could be automatically restored. Compared with the traditional reaction process, as stirring and time-consuming separation processes are not required, the reported catalytic material provides a promising alternative for industrial production. 4 Conclusions In summary, we demonstrate a facile and effective method to fabricate compressible monolithic catalyst, PW12@GF, by combining freeze-drying with low-temperature annealing. The results indicate that PW12 clusters are evenly dispersed on the surface of 3D GF support, and the strong interaction between PW12 and support is confirmed by FT-IR, XPS spectra, and leaching test. The synthesized PW12@GF catalytic material is highly active for biodiesel production and under mild conditions, the conversion of lauric acid reaches 97 %, which is comparable to that of homogeneous PW12 catalyst. Importantly, the esterification reaction was performed without stirring, and the product can be easily separated from the catalyst by compression. The reported PW12@GF as a monolithic catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic activity, elasticity, and recyclability in the biodiesel production and provides a compelling alternative to traditional powder catalysts for continuous industrial production. As POMs have both Brønsted acidity and redox activity, this kind of catalyst can also be used in the oxidation reactions. The present work will inspire the exploration and application of compressible monolithic catalysts, and continuous flow catalysis with the POM-containing monolith is being explored in our lab. coredata.dc:description: Compressible monolithic catalysts exhibit remarkable advantages over traditional powder ones, but the fabrication of polyoxometalate (POM)-containing compressible catalyst is rarely explored. Herein, a compressible monolith, PW12@GF, has been fabricated by immobilizing H3PW12O40 (PW12) catalyst on elastic graphene foam (GF). Moreover, FT-IR and XPS spectra analysis and leaching test reveal that the delocalization of protons on POM occurs during the assembly of PW12@GF, and the delocalized protons connect POM and GF into a stable composite. Importantly, biodiesel production is effectively promoted by PW12@GF under mild conditions (60 °C) without stirring, and the product can be easily separated from the catalyst by compression. Moreover, its catalytic activity is basically maintained after five cycles. Notably, the catalytic activity of PW12@GF (conversion: 97 %) in the heterogeneous system is even comparable to that of homogeneous PW12 and strong Brønsted acidity and the lipophilic surface of the catalyst account for the excellent performance.
coredata.dc:title: Assembly of polyoxometalate with graphene foam as a compressible monolithic catalyst for biodiesel production
